title: Madewell Is Planning an IPO. Here’s What Investors Need to Know.
text:
Text size

Months after Levi Strauss & Co. returned to the public markets, another denim brand intends to join in. Madewell said this month that it plans its own initial public offering.

That would make 2019 a busy year for jeans. The March Levi Strauss (ticker: LEVI) IPO was followed in May by the separation of Kontoor Brands (KTB)—owner of Wrangler and Lee, among other things—from VF Corp. (VFC).

What can investors expect from Madewell? Read on.

First, what is it?

Madewell is a clothing brand that sells in stores and online. Some of its current offerings include women‘s skinny jeans for $138, a men’s corduroy long-sleeve shirt for $88, and nylon backpacks for $118.

“Our motto is ‘Good Days Start with Great Jeans’ because it’s what we truly believe: that stepping into the right pair of jeans is empowering, it makes you feel like the best version of yourself,” wrote CEO Libby Wadle, a former J.Crew and Gap (GPS) executive, in a letter contained in a Sept. 13 pre-IPO filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The brand name itself was acquired in 2005. There were 132 Madewell stores as of Aug. 3, 10 more than a year earlier.

In the filing, the company listed Gap, American Eagle Outfitters (AEOS), and Urban Outfitters (URBN) among its competitors.

How will the offering work?

Madewell, part of privately owned J.Crew Group, is currently known as Chinos Holdings. As part of the IPO, Chinos will be renamed Madewell Group and spun off.

Stuff like the price, timing, exchange for the listing, and ticker symbol hasn’t been disclosed. The company hasn’t said how many shares will be sold or how much money it expects to raise.

But Madewell has said some of the proceeds will be used to pay down debt, while some will go toward general corporate purposes.

And in separate filings last week, J.Crew suggested an enterprise value—combining the value of the stock with its debt and cash—of between $2.5 billion and $2.8 billion. The company, those filings said, could raise $970 million in the deal. (The fillings said some of the “potential values” mentioned were for illustrative purposes only.)

So is Madewell growing?

On Sept. 13, J.Crew said Madewell’s second-quarter revenues rose 15% year over year, to $139.7 million, as sales at stores open at least a year rose 10%. (J.Crew, by comparison, saw sales fall 7% to $399.1 million as same-store sales fell 4%.)

Revenues for the full year ended Feb. 2 were $613.7 million, up from $463.5 million a year earlier. Gross margins were 48%, down from about 50% the previous year.

“We intend to grow our business by, among other things, increasing brand awareness and the size and value of our active customer base, growing e-commerce penetration, expanding our store network and product categories and growing our wholesale business, both domestically and internationally,” the company’s pre-IPO filing said.

Madewell expects to open 10 to 15 stores a year. Meanwhile, it wants to drive “outsize growth in e-commerce,” according to its filling. Digital sales represented about 36% of the company’s total revenue in the first half of the current fiscal year.

Retail is a rough business these days, as both Madewell’s growth and the pitfalls that have beset many of its competitors illustrate. Tastes change abruptly, letting new entrants grow quickly. Established brands can fall out of favor, but they also have resources that can help them push back.

Does Madewell make money?

In Madewell’s pre-IPO filing, it reported first-half net income of $36 million, up from $28 million a year earlier. Net margins were roughly 11% in both cases. In the last full fiscal year, net income was $60 million, up from about $44 million, while net margins were just below 10%.

Some apparel companies sell a lot of foreign-made goods. What about Madewell?

The company said 60% of its merchandise came form China in fiscal 2018, with another 20% coming from either Vietnam or Indonesia. The U.S. accounted for 1%. That could pose challenges for Madewell if trade tensions between the U.S. and China escalate.

Email David Marino-Nachison at david.marino-nachison@barrons.com. Follow him at @marinonachison and follow Barron’s Next at @barronsnext.
description: Months after Levi Strauss & Co. returned to the public markets, another denim brand intends to join in.
